heart attack.title: Heart Attack (Myocardial Infarction)
heart attack.summary: A heart attack occurs when blood flow to a portion of the heart is blocked, typically by a blood clot or plaque rupture in a coronary artery, leading to oxygen deprivation and heart muscle damage. Prompt treatment is critical to minimize damage and improve survival rates.
symptoms: Chest pain or discomfort (pressure, squeezing, or fullness, often radiating to the left arm, jaw, neck, or back)
Shortness of breath, with or without chest pain
Cold sweats, nausea, or vomiting
Lightheadedness, dizziness, or fainting
Unusual fatigue, especially in women
prevention: Quit smoking and avoid secondhand smoke exposure
Follow a heart-healthy diet low in saturated fats, trans fats, and cholesterol (e.g., Mediterranean diet)
Engage in at least 150 minutes of moderate aerobic exercise weekly (e.g., brisk walking, cycling)
Manage risk factors like hypertension, diabetes, and high cholesterol through regular monitoring
Maintain a healthy weight (BMI 18.5â€“24.9)
treatment: Call emergency services immediately (within minutes of symptom onset)
Chew aspirin (if advised by a doctor) to reduce clotting
Emergency procedures like percutaneous coronary intervention (angioplasty) or coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG)
Medications such as beta-blockers, ACE inhibitors, or statins for recovery
Cardiac rehabilitation to restore heart health

hypertension.title: Hypertension (High Blood Pressure)
hypertension.summary: Hypertension is a condition where blood pressure consistently exceeds 130/80 mmHg, straining the heart and blood vessels. Known as the 'silent killer,' it often lacks symptoms but significantly increases risks of heart disease, stroke, and kidney failure.
symptoms: Often asymptomatic, detected only through blood pressure checks
Severe cases may cause headaches, blurred vision, dizziness, or nosebleeds
Chest pain or shortness of breath in advanced stages
prevention: Limit sodium intake to less than 2,300 mg/day (ideally 1,500 mg for high-risk individuals)
Consume a diet rich in fruits, vegetables, whole grains, and low-fat dairy (e.g., DASH diet)
Perform regular physical activity (30 minutes most days of the week)
Reduce stress through mindfulness, meditation, or yoga
Limit alcohol to 1 drink/day for women, 2 for men, and quit smoking
treatment: Lifestyle modifications (diet, exercise, stress management)
Medications like ACE inhibitors, diuretics, beta-blockers, or calcium channel blockers as prescribed
Regular blood pressure monitoring at home or with a healthcare provider

cholesterol.title: High Cholesterol (Hyperlipidemia)
cholesterol.summary: High cholesterol occurs when excessive low-density lipoprotein (LDL) or triglycerides accumulate in the blood, forming plaque in arteries (atherosclerosis), which increases the risk of heart attack and stroke.
symptoms: Typically asymptomatic, detected via blood tests (lipid panel)
Visible signs like xanthomas (fatty deposits under the skin) in rare cases
Chest pain or other heart disease symptoms if arteries are significantly blocked
prevention: Reduce intake of saturated fats (e.g., red meat, full-fat dairy) and eliminate trans fats (e.g., fried foods, packaged snacks)
Increase fiber-rich foods (e.g., oats, beans, fruits) and healthy fats (e.g., avocados, olive oil)
Engage in regular aerobic exercise (e.g., 150 minutes/week of moderate activity)
Maintain a healthy weight and avoid smoking
treatment: Lifestyle changes focusing on diet and exercise
Medications like statins, fibrates, or PCSK9 inhibitors as prescribed
Regular lipid profile tests to monitor LDL, HDL, and triglycerides

stroke.title: Stroke (Cerebrovascular Accident)
stroke.summary: A stroke occurs when blood flow to the brain is interrupted (ischemic stroke) or a blood vessel bursts (hemorrhagic stroke), causing brain cell damage. Rapid treatment within the 'golden hour' is critical to minimize brain damage.
symptoms: Sudden numbness or weakness in the face, arm, or leg (often one-sided)
Sudden confusion, trouble speaking, or understanding speech
Sudden vision loss in one or both eyes
Sudden difficulty walking, loss of balance, or coordination
Sudden severe headache with no known cause
prevention: Control blood pressure (target <130/80 mmHg) and diabetes (HbA1c <7%)
Quit smoking and limit alcohol consumption
Engage in regular physical activity (e.g., 30 minutes of brisk walking daily)
Follow a heart-healthy diet low in sodium and rich in fruits and vegetables
Manage atrial fibrillation with anticoagulants if prescribed
treatment: Immediate emergency care (e.g., clot-busting drugs like tPA for ischemic stroke within 4.5 hours)
Surgical interventions (e.g., thrombectomy, aneurysm clipping) for severe cases
Rehabilitation including physical, occupational, and speech therapy

heart failure.title: Heart Failure
heart failure.summary: Heart failure is a chronic condition where the heart cannot pump blood effectively to meet the body's needs, often due to weakened heart muscles from prior heart attack, hypertension, or cardiomyopathy.
symptoms: Shortness of breath during activity or when lying down (orthopnea)
Swelling (edema) in legs, ankles, feet, or abdomen
Persistent fatigue or weakness
Rapid or irregular heartbeat
Reduced exercise tolerance
prevention: Manage underlying conditions like hypertension, diabetes, and coronary artery disease
Adopt a low-sodium diet (<2,000 mg/day) to reduce fluid retention
Engage in moderate exercise as advised by a doctor
Avoid smoking, excessive alcohol, and illicit drugs
treatment: Medications like diuretics, ACE inhibitors, beta-blockers, or aldosterone antagonists
Device therapy (e.g., implantable cardioverter-defibrillator or pacemaker)
Lifestyle changes and careful monitoring of fluid intake and weight
Heart transplant in severe cases

arrhythmia.title: Heart Arrhythmia
arrhythmia.summary: Arrhythmias are abnormal heart rhythms (too fast, too slow, or irregular) caused by electrical system malfunctions. Common types include atrial fibrillation, bradycardia, and ventricular tachycardia.
symptoms: Palpitations (fluttering or pounding in the chest)
Dizziness, lightheadedness, or fainting (syncope)
Shortness of breath or chest discomfort
Fatigue or weakness
Asymptomatic in some cases
prevention: Avoid triggers like excessive caffeine, alcohol, or nicotine
Manage stress with relaxation techniques (e.g., yoga, meditation)
Control underlying conditions like hypertension or thyroid disease
Regular heart checkups with ECG monitoring
treatment: Medications like antiarrhythmics, beta-blockers, or anticoagulants (for stroke prevention in atrial fibrillation)
Procedures like catheter ablation or cardioversion
Implantation of devices such as pacemakers or defibrillators

coronary artery disease.title: Coronary Artery Disease (CAD)
coronary artery disease.summary: Coronary artery disease develops when the coronary arteries become narrowed or blocked by plaque, reducing blood flow to the heart and increasing the risk of angina or heart attack.
symptoms: Chest pain or discomfort (angina), often triggered by exertion or stress
Shortness of breath
Fatigue or weakness during physical activity
Pain radiating to arms, shoulders, or jaw
prevention: Adopt a heart-healthy diet low in saturated fats and high in fiber
Exercise regularly (150 minutes/week of moderate aerobic activity)
Quit smoking and limit alcohol intake
Manage cholesterol, blood pressure, and diabetes
treatment: Medications like statins, antiplatelets (e.g., aspirin), or beta-blockers
Procedures like angioplasty with stent placement or coronary artery bypass grafting
Lifestyle changes and cardiac rehabilitation

cardiomyopathy.title: Cardiomyopathy
cardiomyopathy.summary: Cardiomyopathy refers to diseases of the heart muscle that impair its ability to pump blood effectively, potentially leading to heart failure or arrhythmias. Types include dilated, hypertrophic, and restrictive cardiomyopathy.
symptoms: Shortness of breath, especially during exertion
Fatigue and weakness
Swelling in legs, ankles, or abdomen
Irregular heartbeats or palpitations
Dizziness or fainting
prevention: Manage underlying conditions like hypertension or diabetes
Avoid excessive alcohol and illicit drug use
Regular medical checkups to monitor heart function
Genetic screening if family history exists
treatment: Medications like beta-blockers, ACE inhibitors, or diuretics
Implantable devices like defibrillators for high-risk patients
Surgical options like septal myectomy for hypertrophic cardiomyopathy
Heart transplant in severe cases
